div.p: Mrs Ellen Smith,
111 Hatton Street,
Jackson,
Tenn,
Camp Meade Maryland
Dear Ellen:

Well I will try an answer your letter which I received yesterday And there is no use telling you how murch I enjoyed it, for you can amagine how murch I do enjoy them for I always answer the first chance I get and hope you will do the same

Well it is snowing here to night and I guess when I get up in the A.M. there will be about 6" of Snow and I do hate to see it we have had so murch bad weather here. There has been snow on the ground ever since I got to this place. And looks like there will be all Winter.
I will be glad when spring comes. It is colder here than it is at home but I am getting use to it now
It rained here last Sunday Night and it froze on the ground so that left about 2" of Ice on the ground
I tell you it was so slick I couldnt stand up The ground flew up and hit
me to day and I fell so hard liked to have jared my teeth loose. But I have had the pleasure of laughing at the other boys so they get even on me.
Well you dont wish any more than I do that some one would get Kaiser Bill so I could come home and stay and quit Kaiser hunting.
Say some one wrote me that Cecie had got his papers back from war department and he was in the first class I know she will hate to see him go and I dont blame her a bit

But we all have to do things we dont want to do. I didnt want to come My self but I am here just the same And I am glad I am here for I wouldnt want to wait and be drafted I had rather Volunteere I dont think it any disgrace but I just rather enlist
Part of the 23 Engineers will leave for France about the first of Feb. And the rest will follow as soon as they can get ready.
I am thinking of transfering to another Regt. I dont know yet whether I will or not

But I gave in My Name last night they say that there is too many men in this regt. and they are going to transfer some out to another regt. So if I am one of the bunch I dont know where I will go. I am not sure I will just give my name.

I sure hope Sue Mae husban get well for I thank I had rather die any where else on earth than in the army We have some to die most ever day and no body seems to care. They do a little for a fellow they blow the bugle when one dies.
Well tell Bob I am foolish about my dishes All I have is a tin pan knife fork spoon and little old tin cup some out fit I will tell you And what I have to put in them is just as bad as the dishes
I have beans 3 times a day and for a change we have beef stew and soup I have eat that stuff untill I dream about it at night

If I ever get a chance to go to town I am going to have a good meal once more just to see how I will feel. My Mother sent me a Christmas box. she put a fruit jar in with some Country Sausage in it and of course the jar had to get broke and lliked to have ruined the hole box

Everett wife sent me a box of Candy and the box bursted open and lost about half of it I say I have hard luck Well I am use to it I have had hard luck all my life so I guess I just as well have it in the army as any where else
I know Everett and Floy are some sweet to each other, but I guess they will get over that some day I would like to be there I sure would have some fun out of them
I dont see why you thank I would get tired of reading your letters I will tell you I dont and want you to write me all you can and as often as you can find the time
From a real true friend
Fayette
23 Engineers Recruiting Detachment Camp Meade Md.
